Headline: CEO & Managing Director at Teligenz Tech Solutions Pvt Ltd
Comment:
India needs its own model, absolutely.

We may not be well served by models that de-emphasize hiring, or emphasize growth at any cost.

What we need are models that result in sustainable employment generation, sustainable growth.

The reason the IT services industry has worked so well, is because of this. But obviously there are issues with that model - it was perfect for a previous generation. We have to build a better model for today - higher up the value chain, delivering better results per employee.

Headline: Building scalable simulation pipelines for AI and synthetic data | Co-Founder @ Avkalan Labs | IIT Roorkee Gold Medalist
Comment:
This really resonates. I was recently discussing with my co-founder (based in the US) how differently things function at a systems level ‚Äî the way structure, risk, and innovation are approached is fundamentally different from what we see here.

In our conversations with VCs here, we‚Äôve observed that there can be some hesitation around newer, less familiar technologies. This cautious approach, while understandable, can sometimes become a bottleneck for early-stage startups working on disruptive or deep-tech ideas that need early belief to grow.

It would be great to see more founder-first micro VCs who truly resonate with the risk-return-impact mindset.

Really inspiring to see you holding this vision, Dilip. That kind of aligned mindset is what fuels real innovation - not "destructive" interference, but "resonating" belief.

Headline: Engineering @ Salesforce
Comment:
I agree with everything you said, but I think we need to look beyond just the lack of a strong narrative. Saying India's main problem is storytelling or marketing feels like we're missing the real issue ‚Äî which is focus.

A lot of the well-known ‚Äúdropout founders‚Äù from Harvard or Stanford got into those colleges just to drop out and use the brand name to raise money. Their businesses often aim for quick profits by serving mass markets ‚Äî not real innovation. In India, we‚Äôve copied the outer layer of that model ‚Äî the hype, fast growth, and name-dropping ‚Äî but without the systems or culture to support it.

Many of India‚Äôs biggest startups aren't led by founders trying to solve real problems. They're more focused on PR and attention than on building long-term solutions. That‚Äôs why we got 10-minute grocery delivery before we fixed Bengaluru‚Äôs traffic, Delhi‚Äôs air pollution, or the lack of affordable housing in crowded cities.

Maybe we don‚Äôt need a YC-style program in India. Maybe what we need is something slower, more thoughtful, and truly built for the challenges we face here.

Headline: Early-Stage Investing @ PedalStart | Backing Founders Building in India | Ex-National Skater, Founder & Operator
Comment:
One thing to add is that India is a fast-growing economy, but also one that‚Äôs had the benefit (and burden) of watching mature markets evolve before us. In many ways, we‚Äôre standing on the shoulders of ecosystems that took the bold risks, so we don‚Äôt always need to reinvent the wheel or absorb the same hits.

And while it‚Äôs true that we might never have a YC-style moment, it doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt create something uniquely Indian. The few risk-takers we do have might be small in number, but they‚Äôll define the narrative shift with the right kind of capital and storytelling.

Headline: Engineer / Data Scientist / Business Analyst | Bridging Tech, Data & Business
Comment:
Totally agree that YC was a product of a unique cocktail‚Äîtime, place, culture‚Äîand blindly replicating it here may miss the point. But maybe the problem is exactly that: we keep trying to copy-paste playbooks from other economies without adapting them to our context. India needs its own blueprint.

That said, I still admire those taking inspiration from YC to build founder-first ecosystems here. The intent matters. Because the gap between the rising number of aspiring entrepreneurs and the kind of real, thoughtful support available is still very real. We need systems that understand Indian founders‚Äînot just fund them.

Headline: Founder @ OneAnt - Save more when you buy together
Comment:
Dilip Kumar, as someone who's been a huge fan of YC, binge-watching demo days, studying their essays, quoting Paul Graham like gospel I‚Äôve always felt this quiet discomfort whenever people said, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs just recreate YC here.‚Äù
It always felt... incomplete. Like copying the shape of something without understanding the soil it grew from.
Silicon Valley in the mid-2000s was a wild experiment of cheap failure and expensive dreams.
India, for better or worse, was (and still is) a country where failure costs real social capital, not just dollars.

Comment:
Dilip Kumar Do you think this will actually happen in India?
I believe this is a deep-rooted issue in the Indian mindset. I‚Äôve studied a lot of YC content on fundraising, but what they teach doesn‚Äôt work in early-stage investor meetings in India. Headline: The future of performance is employee-owned‚Äîwe're making it happen in IT/ITES.
Comment:
I agree with your insights on the lower cost of risk and capital, but I respectfully disagree that we can't have a YC-equivalent here. If you look at the data from some of YC's batches, more than 50% of the companies originate from outside the U.S.

          Take a look at the stats from the YC Summer 2021 batch:

                    377 companies across 47 countries, representing over 4 billion people worldwide.
                    About 50% of the companies were based outside the U.S.. Top countries, excluding the U.S., included:
                    India (33)
                    UK (18)
                    Mexico (17)
                    Canada (18)
                    Brazil (11)
                    Singapore (12)

         These numbers demonstrate the growing global appeal and the increasing talent coming from non-U.S. countries. With India's thriving startup ecosystem and an abundance of entrepreneurial talent, there‚Äôs definitely potential to create a YC-like model right here.

"Bharat Combinator" :) :) :) 

Ciju Baby, COO, https://www.pplio.com

Headline: Ex-Analyst, ED‚Äôs office @ CDFI-IFMR | SAC,DU‚Äô23
Comment:
From what I understand, this is the case because a lot of VC funds raise money from LPs that are not Indian and see these investments akin to the ones that are made in the public markets, backing the possibility of plain pecuniary return over taking the risk of funding something disruptive. Even the completely indian funds in terms of teams and LPs tend not to fund ideas till it has already generated some amount of traction - this significantly cuts down on the risk capital available for innovation that can disrupt the reality as we see today (say, for example flying taxis - a place where there is active investment in India). Even when such capital is available, it is available at tiny ticket sizes (INR 1- 2cr), which puts pressure on the innovator to continuously return to markets to raise money and move to market with either a product that's not too different from run of the mill products available to as the pressure to derisk more and more with for every new investment mounts.
The closest thing that I have seen to the Y-Combinator ecosystem in India are the IITM Incubation Cell and INCeNSE (IISc incubation cell), which work on innovative ideas that can make an impact.

Prestige will follow outcomes, not pedigrees.

Headline: tal64.com
Comment:
Based on my limited understanding, YC is great at coaching founders and inculcating a high tolerance for failure. In India, the quality of entrepreneurship coaching and mentorship is limited to founders who have had scarcity/survival mindset hence you get an ecosystem limited to those type of founders. Also as the MD of one of India's largest companies once mentioned to me, Indians are fundamentally low integrity (dishonest)--which makes it difficult to have a YC like system in the first place. If you are fighting for survival and fear failure, it is not surprising that you are also dishonest--we will be incentivised to be high integrity if we live in a society that doesn't discrimnate against failure/mistakes. 

At a base level, we lie because we are scared.

Long way to go till we have our own Gingko. We can keep on manufacturing cheap knock-offs of Whoop or some such service based products that bring us value, but tech that changes our way of life of impacts humankind will not originate in India. And that, I think is ok. The purpose of a business is to make money, as long as we make money from cheap knockoffs we should be happy about keeping our LPs on the same page. The sooner we accept this the better it is for us.
